prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Observe at band 4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will observe H2CO, HDCO and DCO lines at band 4 to study the kinematics and chemistry of both the very young class 0 protostar (G192N) and the very low-mass object (G192S).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The linewidth of optically thin lines (e.g. HDCO, DCO) is about 0.5 km/s. Thus, we need high spectral resolution (<0.1 km/s) to resolve their line profile and study the kinematics. H2CO has broader linewidth, a spectral resolution of 0.13 km/s is enough to resolve its profile.

Most Keplerian disks reported toward Class 0 objects have sizes of 100-150 AU (Codella et al. 2014). However, the disk sizes of our sources might be much smaller. In the SMA observations, the angular size of the northern continuum source is ~5 arcsec. A long baseline configuration of 12-m array at band 4 with a spatial resolution of <0.25 arcsec could not recover such large structure. Thus, we request angular resolutions of 0.25 arcsec (~95 AU) at band 4 and 0.1 arcsec (~37 AU) at band 7 to resolve the disks and also recover the largest angular (~5 arcsec) structure in source. We need not ACA for disk studies.

In another Class 0 source IRAS 04368 + 2557 in L1527, H2CO 5(1,4)-4(1,4) has a flux density of more than 400 mJy/beam (Sakai et al. 2014). From RADEX calculation, we found that the lower excition transion H2CO 2(0,2)-1(0,1) line usualy has a flux density 7 times larger than H2CO 5(1,4)-4(1,4). Assuming that the two objects in G192.32-11.87 have similar excitation condition for H2CO as in L1527, we expect that the H2CO 2(0,2)-1(0,1) line in our ALMA observations has a flux density of ~0.3 Jy/beam considering the distance difffence. From our single-dish observations, we found that the peak flux density of HDCO 2(0,2)-1(0,1) is about one third of H2CO 2(0,2)-1(0,1) line. Thus, in ALMA observations, HDCO 2(0,2)-1(0,1) should have a flux density of at least 100 mJy/beam, which means that we can detect this line with a S/N>10. The linewidth of HDCO is about 0.5 km/s. Thus, we need the highest spectral resolution (0.07 km/s) to resolve the line profile and to study the kinematics. We will smooth the spectra to get higher S/N if necessary.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: observe at band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will observe CO, SiO, H13CN and some SO or SO2 lines at band 7 to study the kinematics and chemistry of both the very young class 0 protostar (G192N) and the very low-mass object (G192S).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For optically thin lines (e.g. H13CN, H13CO), which have small line widths, we request high spectral resolution of ~0.1 km/s to resolve line profiles and study disk kinematics. For the optically thick lines (e.g. CO, SiO), which may have broader line widths, we request a spectral resolution of ~1 km/s.

Most Keplerian disks reported toward Class 0 objects have sizes of 100-150 AU (Codella et al. 2014). However, the disk sizes of our sources might be much smaller. In the SMA observations, the angular size of the northern continuum source is ~5 arcsec. A long baseline configuration of 12-m array at band 4 with a spatial resolution of <0.25 arcsec could not recover such large structure. Thus, we request angular resolutions of 0.25 arcsec (~95 AU) at band 4 and 0.1 arcsec (~37 AU) at band 7 to resolve the disks and also recover the largest angular (~5 arcsec) structure in source. The ouflows might have larger angular structure which could not be recovered by the ALMA. We will apply the SMA and the JCMT observations to recover the large angular structure of outflows. With the ALMA, we only hope to detect the inner jets and outflows close to the envelope. Thus, we do not need ACA.

HH 212 has similar continuum intensity as the northern source (G192N) in G192.32-11.87. With ALMA, HCO+ (4-3) emission toward HH 212 has a flux density of 1 Jy/beam with a beam size of 0.5 arcsec. Assuming that HCO+ (4-3) toward G192.32-11.87 has similar flux as HH212 and the line emission is gaussian distributed, we expect that HCO+ (4-3) line will have a peak flux density of 200 mJy/beam with a beam size of 0.1 arcsec. The peak flux density of H13CO (4-3) estimated with RADEX is at least 50 mJy/beam. The desired RMS is enough to detect this line with S/N>5. The linewidth of H13CO (1-0) from single-dish observations is about 0.5 km/s. Thus, we need the high spectral resolution (~0.1 km/s) to resolve the line profile and study the kinematics. We will smooth the spectra to get higher S/N if necessary. With the requested rms, we should very easily detect other strong emission lines (e.g. CO).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Rotationally supported disks (RSD) are crucial for star formation and planet formation. In spite of their importance, it is still not well understood how and when RSDs are formed and whether their formation is affected by the environment. Additionally, are those very low-mass (VLM) objects (e.g. brown dwarfs) also formed through disk accretion as more massive stars like the Sun? To answer these questions, we propose high sensitivity (~10 mJy/beam for lines) and high resolution (0.1-0.25 arcsec) ALMA observations to measure the rotationally supported disk toward an extremely young Class 0 protostar (G192N) and a proto-brown dwarf candidate (G192S) both located within the bight rimmed cloud G192.32-11.87. We will try to resolve their disks and to study disk's kinematics and interaction with the envelope through modeling molecular lines (e.g. H2CO, HDCO, H13CN). We will also study the chemcial properties of the disk and the envelope. Our observations will for the first time explore disk formation in an extreme environment (a bright rimmed cloud), which are entirely different from those nearby and less dense cores, on which most of previous disk studies have focused.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Radio Astronomy Division, Korea Astronomy and Space Science Institute
